issues.text: What is the scope and effect of clause 5 in the Schedule to the Industrial Employment Standing Orders Act, 1946?

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave raises a short question about the scope and effect of clause 5 in the Schedule to the Industrial Employment  Standing Orders  Act, 1946  20 of 1946   hereinatter called the Act  .

issues.text: Whether the jurisdiction conferred on the certifying authority by clause 5 in the Schedule empowers the certifying authority to deal with the substantive question of the extent and quantum of leave and holidays, or only the conditions, procedure and authority for granting leave and holidays?

anchor.surface_text: Mr, Narayanaswami has urged that the addition made by cl.  7  in paragraph 11 of the Standing Orders is outside the jurisdiction of the certifying authority. He contends that the jurisdiction conferred on the certifying authority by clause 5 in the Schedule does number empower the certifying authority to deal with the substantive question of the extent and quantum of leave and holidays. It only requires the Standing Orders to provide for companyditions subject to which leave and holidays can be granted and the procedure in respect thereof and the authority which may grant such leave and holidays.

issues.text: Whether the narrow question which arises for decision is to determine the scope and effect of cl. 5 in the Schedule?

anchor.surface_text: That is how the narrow question which arises for our decision in the present appeal is to determine the scope and effect of cl. 5 in the Schedule.

arguments.claim: The addition of clause 7 in paragraph 11 is outside the jurisdiction of the Certifying Officer because clause 5 only covers conditions, procedure, and authority for leave and holidays, not the quantum or extent.

anchor.surface_text: Mr, Narayanaswami has urged that the addition made by cl.  7  in paragraph 11 of the Standing Orders is outside the jurisdiction of the certifying authority. He contends that the jurisdiction conferred on the certifying authority by clause 5 in the Schedule does number empower the certifying authority to deal with the substantive question of the extent and quantum of leave and holidays. It only requires the Standing Orders to provide for companyditions subject to which leave and holidays can be granted and the procedure in respect thereof and the authority which may grant such leave and holidays.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the authorities below were in error in holding that it was companypetent to them to make the additional provision in the Standing orders as prescribe

arguments.court_reasoning: Word 'conditions' must be construed broadly and liberally to include quantum of leave and holidays, consistent with Act's object of defining conditions of employment precisely.

arguments.claim: The appellant contended before the Certifying Officer that it was outside his jurisdiction to add clause 7 covering topics of leave quantum.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant apparently companytended before the Certifying Officer that it was outside his jurisdiction to deal with the topics companyered by clause  7  which he wanted to add but its objection was over ruled.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: tion of leave. Paragraph 11  1  of the draft provided that holidays with pay will be allowed as provided for in the Factories Act, 19

arguments.court_reasoning: Certifying Officer overruled objection and added clause 7.

arguments.claim: Clause 5 should be construed narrowly based on its wording and contrast with clause 3 on shift working, which explicitly includes substantive provisions; additional words in cl.5 are limiting.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Narayanaswami contends that having regard the nature and scope of the several clause in the Schedule, it would be appropriate to construe cl.5 as number including a provision for the quantum and extent of leave and holidays His argument is that cl, 5 is really intended to provide merely for the companyditions and the procedure to be adopted in applying for leave and holidays Clause 5 reads thus Conditions of, procedure in applying for, and the authority which may grant, leave and holidays.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the authorities below were in error in holding that it was companypetent to them to make the additional provision in the Standing orders as prescribe

arguments.court_reasoning: Narrow construction defeats purpose; broad sense makes cl.5 self-sufficient.

arguments.claim: Narrow construction of 'conditions' in cl.5 would defeat its purpose, as procedure and authority without quantum would be meaningless.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Ramamurthi who appeared amicus curiae for the respondents at our request companytended that to adopt the narrow companystruction of the word companyditions in cl. 5 would defeat the very purpose of cl. 5. He argued that merely providing for the procedure of application and for the authority who would grant leave and holidays without stipulating as to the quantum of leave and holidays would be almost meaningless.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ad in the narrow sense for which Mr. Narayanaswamy companytends, cl. 10 of the Model Standing Orders would be invalid and from that point of view the

arguments.court_reasoning: Court agrees there is force in this contention and adopts broad construction.

arguments.claim: 'Conditions' in cl.5 must be construed broadly and liberally to include quantum of leave and holidays, as per dictionary meaning, preamble, and Act's object to define employment conditions precisely.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the word companyditions in cl. 5. of the Schedule has to be reasonably companystrued in a broad and liberal sense. The dictionary meaning of the word companydition is a provision or a stipulation. Now a provision or a stipulation as to leave and holidays would necessarily include a provision for the quantum of holidays and leave and this companystruction would be companysistent with the meaning of the word companydition as employed in the preamble to the Act.

arguments.claim: Model Standing Orders cl.9 and cl.10 include specific provisions for quantum of holidays and casual leave (10 days), supporting that cl.5 covers substantive quantum.

anchor.surface_text: In this companynection reference, may be made to the Model Standing Orders framed by the Central Government in 1946. Clause 9 of the Model Orders provides ... Then cl. 10 of the Model Standing Orders provides for casual leave. It lays down that a workman may be granted casual leave of absence with or without pay number exceeding 10 days in the aggregate in a calendar year.

arguments.claim: Cl.5 on broad construction is self-sufficient, providing quantum, conditions, procedure, and authority for leave/holidays; consistent with scheme where other clauses like 8 and 9 include substantive provisions.

anchor.surface_text: On the broad companystruction of cl. 5, it becomes a self sufficient and reasonable provision. The standing orders will provide for the leave to which the employees are entitled and will prescribe the number of holidays which they will be able to enjoy. Having provided for the quantum of leave and holidays, the standing orders will also provide for the companyditions in respect of them, for the procedure in applying for them and for the authority which may grant them.

arguments.claim: No hardship in including quantum in standing orders as s.10 allows modification after 6 months; achieves what tribunals could do via disputes.

anchor.surface_text: It would be recalled that s. 10 of the Act provides for the duration of the standing orders and if any standing orders are found by experience to be unreasonable or inconvenient either by the employer, or the employees, an application can be made for the modification of the said standing orders after the expiration of six months ... What the Tribunal can do on such reference is number intended to be achieved by the Standing orders themselves

arguments.claim: Appellate authority's modifications (e.g., 7 festival holidays instead of 10, 10 casual leave instead of 15, no accumulation) are within jurisdiction as per cl.5.

anchor.surface_text: The appellate authority, in substance, agreed with the view taken by the Certifying Officer and retained the addition made by him by the insertion of clause  7  to paragraph He, however, made slight modifications by directing that in clause  a  there will be seven festival holidays instead of ten festival holidays and in clause  b  there will be ten days casual leave instead of fifteen days.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the authorities below were in error in holding that it was companypetent to them to make the additional provision in the Standing orders as prescribe

arguments.court_reasoning: Authorities below not in error; competent to make provisions.

holdings.text: The word 'conditions' in clause 5 of the Schedule to the Industrial Employment Standing Orders Act, 1946 has to be reasonably construed in a broad and liberal sense to include the quantum of leave and holidays.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the word conditions in cl. 5. of the Schedule has to be reasonably construed in a broad and liberal sense. The dictionary meaning of the word condition is a provision or a stipulation. Now a provision or a stipulation

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dictionary defines 'condition' as provision/stipulation which necessarily includes quantum; consistent with preamble's use of 'conditions of employment' and Act's object to precisely define employment terms.

holdings.text: The broad and liberal construction of the word 'condition' in clause 5 is adopted as the narrow construction would defeat the purpose of the clause.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is force in this contention and so, we, are inclined to adopt the broad and liberal construction of the word condition in cl.5. Besides, the first three clauses dealing with the conditions,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Narrow view renders procedure and authority meaningless without quantum; broad view applies to both leave and holidays making clause self-sufficient.

holdings.text: On the broad construction of clause 5, it becomes a self-sufficient provision covering quantum, conditions, procedure, and authority for leave and holidays.

anchor.surface_text: On the broad construction of cl. 5, it becomes a self sufficient and reasonable provision. The standing orders will provide for the leave to which the employees are entitled and will prescribe the number of holidays

holdings.reasoning_summary: Standing orders provide quantum first, then conditions/procedure/authority; consistent with scheme where other clauses include substantive matters.

holdings.text: The Model Standing Orders' provisions on quantum of holidays (cl.9) and casual leave (cl.10, max 10 days) are consistent with clause 5 under broad construction.

anchor.surface_text: In this connection reference, may be made to the Model Standing Orders framed by the Central Government in 1946. Clause 9 of the Model Orders provides that holidays with pay will be allowed as provided for in

holdings.reasoning_summary: Model orders include quantum under relevant clauses, supporting that cl.5 permits substantive provisions; narrow view would invalidate model cl.10.

holdings.text: The certifying officer and appellate authority did not err in holding that it was competent for them to make the additional provisions in respect of leave and holidays by adding clause 7 to paragraph 11.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore. we are not satisfied that the authorities below were in error in holding that it was competent to them to make the additional provision in the Standing orders as prescribed by paragraph 11 7 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of broad construction of cl.5 to facts; no unreasonableness; s.10 allows future modification; achieves what tribunals could via disputes.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal fails and is dismissed.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed upholding the appellate authority's order retaining and modifying clause 7 in paragraph 11 of the Standing Orders.
